entry.title: Re: Capturing 2 STIP EMP group on Worksheet in SAP SF VPay
entry.content: Hi David, apologies for the delay in responding to your query. In the current system, an employee can be part of two STIP groups within the same year. Currently, there's no option to aggregate the payout amount‚Äîwe pay based on the group where the employee has spent the most time during the year. Also, good to note that we don‚Äôt have individual or team-level scorecards. The payout is solely based on overall company performance.

entry.title: SAP TechEd Berlin 2025: DA263 | SAP HANA Cloud - Advisors and automation
entry.content:
A couple of words about me:

My name is Jinhee Jeong and I‚Äôm a Product Manager for SAP HANA Cloud, with a focus on Intelligent Automation involving various advisors and automation features for cloud database administration and optimization.

 

My session:

DA263 | SAP HANA Cloud: Advisors and automation

Nov 6 (Thursday) / 9:00 AM - 11:00 AM CET

 

What you will learn about:

This hands-on workshop session will transform how you optimize your SAP HANA Cloud databases! Join me as we explore the powerful intelligent advisors available in HANA Cloud Central, where you'll learn to configure and leverage the Elastic Compute Node Advisor, Partition Advisor, and Index Advisor.

This interactive session is designed to give you practical experience in generating intelligent database optimization recommendations that can improve your system performance. We'll dive deep into the configuration process for each advisor, and learn multiple proven approaches for implementing these recommendations.

Whether you're a database administrator, developer, or SAP professional looking to enhance your optimization skills, this workshop will provide you with actionable insights and hands-on techniques you can apply immediately. Don't miss this opportunity to master these essential tools and take your SAP HANA Cloud database performance to the next level!

 

Other related sessions I recommend:

Related community topic pages:

Looking forward to seeing you:

Ready to supercharge your SAP HANA Cloud database performance? Register now for this hands-on workshop and discover how to unlock the full potential of HANA Cloud Central's intelligent advisors! Space is limited, so secure your spot today and join fellow SAP professionals in mastering these tools.

entry.title: Accept Zero as a valid value in a currency field
entry.content:
Hello,

we have a numeric / currency type field on the database. In this case, the initial status is 0. However, the value 0 should be recognized as a user input in the UI5 frontend during the mandatory field check. I.e. if the field is initially displayed, it must be blank. If the user maintains the zero, this must be recognized as an input.
To do this, we have converted the field in the CDS view into a character field in the UI5.
Now we have the problem that the thousands separators are no longer displayed, which makes readability more difficult for large numbers.

Is there a solution for this problem?
- Database field numerical
- A zero value should be accepted from the user interface as a valid value in a required field check

entry.title: Re: Trigger Equipment Replication (Event Mesh) from S/4HA...
entry.content:
Good day @krri 

Thank you for your question.

Have you had a look at Equipment & Side-by-Side Extensibility with SAP Build Apps -E2E Service covering Customer Service, Field Service?

The summary is, the event-based integration you are trying to carry out only handles changes to existing details (e.g., create, change or delete). There is no built-in initial load through DRF and you cannot replicate models.

  • SAP recommends you use the equipment API to extract all equipment data and push it into your service cloud V2 through CPI or API
  • Alternatively, you can trigger change of events by performing a mass change on a field with no impact. Only do this for small data sets.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Is it Mandatory to have Cloud foundry runtime with Bu...
entry.content:
Having a CF runtime is not mandatory for using BAS, I assume you are going to deploy the FIORI apps back to your S/4 system based.

If not deploying back to S/4 then you will need to have CF runtime for hosting and running your apps. The size will depend on the subaccount strategy and the number of apps that you would deploy in each subaccount and also the load on the application.

I would suggest to go with default size and then scale it as you go.

entry.title: Entity returns duplicate value when used with filters, $top and $skip
entry.content:
We have a CAP Java backend (CAP Java SDK version 4.0.0) with Fiori elements frontend. We use the tree table component in our first list report page of our application. ‚ÄÉ

Tree table in our application : 

So when loading the tree table frontend component, we do the following backend call : 

NameOfOurEntity$apply=orderby(numberOfMetrics%20desc)/com.sap.vocabularies.Hierarchy.v1.TopLevels(HierarchyNodes=$root/NameOfOurEntity,HierarchyQualifier='SystemHierarchy',NodeProperty='id')&$select=DistanceFromRoot,DrillState,LimitedDescendantCount,dataCollectionStatus,dataCollectionStatusLabel,id,name,numberOfMetrics,parentID&$count=true&$skip=0&$top=225

When we apply a filter the following call happens to our backend : 

NameOfOurEntity?$apply=ancestors($root/NameOfOurEntity,SystemHierarchy,id,filter(dataCollectionStatusLabel%20eq%20'NOT_CONFIGURED'),keep%20start)/orderby(numberOfMetrics%20desc)/com.sap.vocabularies.Hierarchy.v1.TopLevels(HierarchyNodes=$root/NameOfOurEntity,HierarchyQualifier='SystemHierarchy',NodeProperty='id')&$select=DistanceFromRoot,DrillState,LimitedDescendantCount,dataCollectionStatus,dataCollectionStatusLabel,id,name,numberOfMetrics,parentID&$count=true&$skip=0&$top=225

Our Backend Entity looks like this : 

 

entity TreeEntityTable as select distinct key id, name, parentID, numberOfMetrics, dataCollectionStatus,
  dataCollectionStatusLabel, serviceType
  from (
    select id, name, parentID, numberOfMetrics, dataCollectionStatus, dataCollectionStatusLabel, serviceType
    from SystemTypes union
    select id, name, parentID, numberOfMetrics, dataCollectionStatus, dataCollectionStatusLabel, serviceType
    from Systems union
    select id, name, parentID, numberOfMetrics, dataCollectionStatus, dataCollectionStatusLabel, serviceType
    from Clients union
    select id, name, parentID, numberOfMetrics, dataCollectionStatus, dataCollectionStatusLabel, serviceType
    from LanscapeObjects
  );
@Capabilities.FilterRestrictions.NonFilterableProperties: [
  'LimitedDescendantCount',
  'DistanceFromRoot',
  'DrillState',
  'LimitedRank',
  'dataCollectionStatus',
  'id',
  'numberOfMetrics',
  'parentID',
  'serviceType'
]
@Capabilities.SortRestrictions.NonSortableProperties: [
  'LimitedDescendantCount',
  'DistanceFromRoot',
  'DrillState',
  'LimitedRank',
  'dataCollectionStatus',
  'id',
  'parentID',
  'serviceType'
]
@cds.search: {
  id,
  name,
  dataCollectionStatusLabel,
  numberOfMetrics,
  serviceType
}
@readonly
entity TreeEntity as projection on TreeEntityTable {
  @title:'{i18n>ID}'
  key id,
  @title:'{i18n>SYSTEM_NAME}'
  name,
  @titl:'{i18n>NUMBER_OF_METRICS}'
  numberOfMetrics,
  @title:'{i18n>DATA_COLLECTION_STATUS}'
  dataCollectionStatus,
  @title:'{i18n>DATA_COLLECTION_STATUS_LABEL}'
  dataCollectionStatusLabel,
  parentID,
  serviceType,
  parent : Association to TreeEntity on parent.id = $self.parentID,
  children : Composition of many TreeEntity on children.parentID = $self.id,
  statusLabelRelation : Association to one TreeEntityTableLabels on statusLabelRelation.dataCollectionStatusLabel = $self.dataCollectionStatusLabel,
  virtual null as LimitedDescendantCount : Integer64,
  virtual null as DistanceFromRoot : Integer64,
  virtual null as DrillState : String,
  virtual null as LimitedRank : Integer64
};

We never expect our backend to return duplicate entries to our frontend but we have see that in few cases when a filter is applied which contains data with more than 1500 entries and when multiple calls to backend with different $top and $skip is fired our backend tends to return duplicate values.

Please do let us know if you have faced the same issue or if you have already come across a fix for it.

entry.title: How to Integrate SAP Commerce with Large Language Models (LLMs) for Intelligent Product Discovery
entry.content:
In the era of AI-driven commerce, product discovery is evolving beyond keyword search and static recommendations. Modern shoppers expect context-aware, conversational, and intent-driven interactions  Show me "budget-friendly noise-canceling headphones for travel"  should instantly return relevant products, not just keyword matches.

Traditional SAP Commerce search engines like Solr or SAP Commerce Search Services work well for structured queries. But they struggle when customers use natural language, fuzzy intents, or multi-attribute requests.

This is where Large Language Models (LLMs) like GPT-4, Claude, or Vertex AI Gemini come in ‚Äî enabling natural understanding of user intent, semantic matching with product data, and even contextual re-ranking.

In this blog, we‚Äôll build an LLM-powered Product Discovery layer on top of SAP Commerce. You‚Äôll learn:

  • How to extract and embed product catalog data.

  • How to build a semantic vector store for products.

  • How to integrate LLM-based intent understanding.

  • How to return ranked, relevant results to the SAP storefront.

Architecture Overview

 

Step 1: Exporting Product Data from SAP Commerce

We first expose a REST API from SAP Commerce that returns key product data for indexing:

// File: ProductExportController.java
package com.aiintegration.controllers;

import de.hybris.platform.commercefacades.product.ProductFacade;
import de.hybris.platform.commercefacades.product.data.ProductData;
import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.*;

import java.util.List;

@RestController
@RequestMapping("/v1/ai/products")
public class ProductExportController {

    private final ProductFacade productFacade;

    public ProductExportController(ProductFacade productFacade) {
        this.productFacade = productFacade;
    }

    @GetMapping
    public List<ProductData> exportProducts() {
        // Export only relevant fields for AI discovery
        return productFacade.getAllProducts().stream()
                .map(p -> {
                    ProductData data = new ProductData();
                    data.setCode(p.getCode());
                    data.setName(p.getName());
                    data.setDescription(p.getDescription());
                    data.setCategory(p.getCategory());
                    data.setPrice(p.getPrice());
                    return data;
                })
                .toList();
    }
}

Step 2: Building the AI Discovery Service (LLM + Vector DB)

Let‚Äôs create a simple AI service that uses OpenAI Embeddings + Qdrant (or Pinecone) for semantic search.

I am using Go Lang here as Go is very powerful , easy to develop & consume less memory. Idea is to externalise the service deploy as side by side in any hyper-scaler environment

Example in Go (using Gin)

package main

import (
    "context"
    "encoding/json"
    "net/http"
    "github.com/gin-gonic/gin"
    openai "github.com/sashabaranov/go-openai"
)

type Product struct {
    Code        string  `json:"code"`
    Name        string  `json:"name"`
    Description string  `json:"description"`
    Category    string  `json:"category"`
    Price       float64 `json:"price"`
}

var client = openai.NewClient("YOUR_OPENAI_API_KEY")
var vectorStore = map[string][]float32{} // Use Qdrant/Pinecone in prod
var productData = []Product{}

func generateEmbeddings(text string) []float32 {
    resp, _ := client.CreateEmbeddings(context.Background(), openai.EmbeddingRequest{
        Input: []string{text},
        Model: openai.AdaEmbeddingV2,
    })
    return resp.Data[0].Embedding
}

func indexProducts(c *gin.Context) {
    json.NewDecoder(c.Request.Body).Decode(&productData)
    for _, p := range productData {
        combined := p.Name + " " + p.Description + " " + p.Category
        vectorStore[p.Code] = generateEmbeddings(combined)
    }
    c.JSON(http.StatusOK, gin.H{"message": "Products indexed"})
}

func searchProducts(c *gin.Context) {
    query := c.Query("q")
    queryVector := generateEmbeddings(query)
    // Compute cosine similarity and rank (simplified)
    results := rankBySimilarity(queryVector)
    c.JSON(http.StatusOK, results)
}

func main() {
    r := gin.Default()
    r.POST("/index", indexProducts)
    r.GET("/search", searchProducts)
    r.Run(":8081")
}

This service indexes SAP Commerce products as embeddings and returns semantic matches for user queries. 

This service can be deployed  in any cloud service provider 

Step 3: Integrating AI Discovery with SAP Storefront

If you‚Äôre using SAP Composable Storefront (Spartacus), you can integrate this AI service easily:

// ai-search.service.ts
@Injectable({ providedIn: 'root' })
export class AiSearchService {
  constructor(private http: HttpClient) {}

  search(query: string): Observable<Product[]> {
    const api = 'https://ai-service.letstravail.com/search?q=' + encodeURIComponent(query);
    return this.http.get<Product[]>(api);
  }
}

And in your Search Results component:

@Component({
  selector: 'cx-ai-search',
  template: `
    <div class="search-container">
      <input [(ngModel)]="query" placeholder="Ask me what you need..." />
      <button (click)="onSearch()">Search</button>

      <div *ngFor="let p of products" class="product-card">
        <h3>{{ p.name }}</h3>
        <p>{{ p.description }}</p>
        <span>{{ p.price | currency }}</span>
      </div>
    </div>
  `
})
export class AiSearchComponent {
  query = '';
  products: Product[] = [];

  constructor(private aiSearch: AiSearchService) {}

  onSearch() {
    this.aiSearch.search(this.query).subscribe(res => this.products = res);
  }
}

Step 4: Intent Understanding with LLMs

For more advanced queries (‚ÄúShow me eco-friendly running shoes under $100‚Äù), we can use GPT-4 or Gemini to extract structured filters from the text:

Example: Query Intent Parsing with GPT

func parseIntent(query string) map[string]interface{} {
    prompt := fmt.Sprintf(`Extract search filters from this query:
    "%s"
    Respond in JSON with keys: category, attributes, priceRange, sentiment`, query)

    resp, _ := client.CreateChatCompletion(context.Background(), openai.ChatCompletionRequest{
        Model: "gpt-4-turbo",
        Messages: []openai.ChatCompletionMessage{
            {Role: "user", Content: prompt},
        },
    })

    var filters map[string]interface{}
    json.Unmarshal([]byte(resp.Choices[0].Message.Content), &filters)
    return filters
}

Example Input:

‚ÄúShow me eco-friendly running shoes under $100‚Äù

LLM OUTPUT

{
  "category": "running shoes",
  "attributes": ["eco-friendly", "sustainable"],
  "priceRange": "<100"
}

These structured filters can refine your SAP Commerce FlexibleSearch or Solr queries for more precise results.

Step 5: Combining Semantic Search + SAP Search

You can now combine  traditional keyword search and LLM-based semantic ranking.

Feature Traditional         Solr Search                     LLM Semantic Search

Query TypeKeyword-basedIntent-based
Fuzzy MatchingLimitedHigh
Multi-attributeComplexNatural
Contextual RankingNoYes
LatencyLowModerate
AccuracyDepends on synonymsLearns semantics

Hybrid Search result example 

// Combine Solr + AI Ranking
List<ProductData> solrResults = solrSearchService.search(query);
List<ProductData> aiResults = aiService.semanticSearch(query);

// Merge based on confidence score
List<ProductData> finalList = mergeResults(solrResults, aiResults);

 Future Extensions

  • Integrate with SAP Joule for enterprise AI context.

  • Use LLM RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) for chatbot-style search.

  • Combine with SAP Commerce Recommendation Services.

  • Deploy the AI service in SAP BTP Kyma (Kubernetes) for scale.

Conclusion

Integrating LLMs with SAP Commerce transforms your storefront into a truly intelligent shopping experience ‚Äî one that understands your customers‚Äô intent, not just their keywords.

By building a semantic layer using embeddings and an LLM-based query parser, you enable human-like product discovery that feels conversational, context-aware, and personalized.

Whether you use OpenAI, Gemini, or SAP Joule, the pattern remains:
Extract ‚Üí Embed ‚Üí Search ‚Üí Rank ‚Üí Learn.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Post Direct Activity Allocation to Event-Ba...
entry.content:
Hi @MOHAMMED_BASER,

Thank you very much for your detailed and helpful response.

Regarding your points:

  1. SSCUI: Activate Account Assignment to Activity Types
    I‚Äôve tried to locate this SSCUI in our system (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508), but I don‚Äôt see it available. Could you please confirm whether this SSCUI is still accessible in version 2508? Or if it has been replaced or integrated into another configuration activity?

  2. G/L Account 55110000
    You are correct ‚Äî the account is currently blocked for posting. However, this account is not used in any automatic account determination settings in our system. I‚Äôve checked the relevant SSCUIs and configuration apps, and I cannot find where this account is being referenced for the direct activity allocation. If you have any suggestions on where else it might be configured or inherited from, I‚Äôd appreciate your input.

  3. WBS Element Configuration
    I‚Äôve reviewed the WBS element setup thoroughly. It is released, correctly assigned to an investment profile that allows internal activity allocation, and not restricted to procurement or AuC-only postings. Everything seems to be in order from that perspective.

  4. Use of F3697A in Event-Based Projects
    According to SAP‚Äôs official documentation (SAP Help Portal ‚Äì Event-Based Settlement), step 4a explicitly lists Manage Direct Activity Allocation (F3697A) as one of the apps that can be used to post costs to investment projects with event-based settlement. This seems to suggest that such postings should be supported, at least under certain conditions.

Let me know if you have any further insights or if there‚Äôs additional documentation I should review. Your guidance is greatly appreciated!

Best regards

Vero

entry.title: How to speed up UI development process using UI5 web components
entry.content:
In the past few weeks I was asked to build a React application to be deployed on BTP. The application needs to be integrated with authentication and destinations to connect to a backend OData API.

I started with the templates available in Build Code to create an application skeleton with these capabilities, and it worked fine. The app communicated via a destination to an OData service deployed in my BTP subaccount; it required authentication. So, at first glance, my job was done.

Then I decided to change the app layout and began modifying the generated components. At that point I realized testing the changes was not straightforward. Running the app locally was possible, but to get the latest changes I had to rebuild the app completely, and that procedure takes time (almost 1 minute).

I wanted a leaner workflow to make changes and test them locally without a full rebuild every time.

Since I‚Äôm not an expert in React development, I asked a colleague, @rpagni, for help. He has solid experience with the framework and said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve faced this problem before ‚Äî let me show you how I solved it.‚Äù His idea was great: use a modern React build tool for faster builds and use the app router to handle both dev and prod versions. That way the app router can easily integrate authentication and backend communication via destinations.

Looking for examples I found this tutorial: https://developers.sap.com/mission.react-spa.html. It uses React and Vite, but unfortunately it doesn‚Äôt connect to a backend service and isn‚Äôt integrated with a multitarget application (MTA).

So, together with @rpagni we decided to document the solution step by step to share our experience. We described every aspect of what we did and explained the choices we made.

 

Steps to create a React application deployable in BTP and using UAA and Destination services

Create Basic Multitarget Application

Open the template wizard and start creating a Multitarget Application project. Assing to the project your preferred name.

Create an Approuter module

In the MTA project create an app router module. To do that:

  1. right click on the mta.yaml file and select Create MTA module from Template.
  2. select Approuter Configuration module
  3. configure the following screen with these values:
    • Application Runtime: Standalone Approuter
    • Add Authentication: Yes
    • Plan to add UI: Yes
  4. if you want to change the app router module name, change the name to the created folder and change, in the mta.yaml file, any reference to the previous folder name with the new name assigned

Change xs-security.json to allow the local app-router to manage authentication

When you run the application, either in dev mode or in production mode, it could happen to get the error:

OpenID provider cannot process the request because the redirect_uri does not match the configuration. Please contact your system administrator.

This is an error related to the authentication process. The app router redirects the user session to the authetication service and this raises an error. The reason is about the fact that the expected redirect URI, provided as parameter to the authentication service, it is not part of the allowed redirect URIs. To solve this issue, add to the xs-security.json the following allowed URIs patterns. Add the following object property to the configuration (adapt the patterns to your specific subaccount URLs):

,
  "oauth2-configuration": {
      "redirect-uris": [
          "https://*.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/login/callback",
          "https://*.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/login/callback",
          "https://*.applicationstudio.cloud.sap/login/callback"
      ]
  }

Crate a React Vite project

Create a React project with your preferred build tool, in this case we use Vite template see an example here. This template will create a React project using the SAPUI5 web components

Open terminal, navigate to the project root folder and run the commands (events-app is the folder name):

npx degit UI5/webcomponents-react/templates/vite-ts#main events-app

cd events-app

npm i

Properly setup Vite project

In the Vite project perform these activities:

  1. change the vite.config.ts with this content:
    import { defineConfig } from "vite"; import react from "@vitejs/plugin-react"; import path from "path";
export default defineConfig({ 
      plugins: [react()], 
      server: { 
        hmr: { port: 5174, }, 
      }, 
      build: { 
        outDir: "../test-react-approuter/dist", 
        emptyOutDir: true, 
      }, 
      resolve: { 
        alias: { 
         "@": path.resolve(__dirname, "./src"), 
        }, 
      }, 
    });

purpose of this code is:

  • setup a fixed port (5174) for the preview service
  • define the build directory: once the project is built, this is the place where to store the built files. This config defines to store the /dist folder within the app router folder, this is needed later on when the routes are defined in the xs-app.json

  • set an alias on the subfolders contained within the react project source folder

  • import the path library typing the command

    npm i path -s

  • in the tsconfig.json add, in the compilerOptions ojects, the 2 properties

     "baseUrl": ".",
 "paths": {
     "@/*": ["./src/*"]
 }

Edit mta.yaml file

The purpose of this edting is to add a resource declaration to define a destination service instance, once the mta will be deployed and add a reference to this service to the app router module. The need of this setting is to allow the app router to access the destination service and connect, via a destination reported withint the xs-app.json, to the backend service needed to consume the corresponding APIs (in my case the APIs managing events data). For doing that proceed as defined here:

  1. in the resources section (end of the file) add a resource defining a destination service instance. For example:
     - name: dest_events-react-app
 type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
 parameters:
     service: destination
     service-name: dest_events-react-app
     service-plan: lite
  2. in the app router module definition, add a reference to such a resource in the requires section:
     requires:
   - name: events-react-app_html_repo_runtime 
       - name: uaa_events-react-app 
       - name: dest_events-react-app
  3. remove the deployer module: having selected the standalone app router as application runtime, the wizard creates.

Build and deploy the project

With this activity the aim is to deploy the mtar file corresponding to this project. The goal is not to have a productive version of the app, but simply to let the deployment process to istantiate the declared xsuaa and destination services. Later you will download the corresponding env data realted to them.

  1. right click on the mta.yaml file and select the build command
  2. once the build is finished, find the generated mtar file, right click on it and select to deploy (be sure to be authenticated to any valid BTP subaccount and space with some available runtime resources assigned).

Once deployed, check in the space applications to find an app named as the app router module.

Setup the app router module to manage both the productive and the development app execution

The goal of this step is to properly structure the app router module in order to let the user both test locally the application without any need of code rebuild and having the application working productively, as well.

Create a dev folder in the module

The purpose of this folder is to define a developer configuration for the app router. The content of this folder is used to serve the application during the development phase and not require any application build process.

  1. create a folder called (for example) dev in the app-approuter folder

  2. open the package.json and change the script start-local with this command:

    node node_modules/@sap/approuter/approuter.js --workingDir dev

    this commanda runs the app router with the configuration defined in the next steps in folder dev

  3. move to folder dev and copy and paste the xs-app.json file, available in the app-approuter folder
  4. create a default-env.json file in the dev folder. This file will be used by the @sap/approuter library to connect to the xsuaa and destination services available in BTP. In this way, during the development phase, the developer can test the authetication/authorization (for example checking whether the assigned scopes are working properly) and the destination connectivity as per the productive version of the app. To create the file:
    1. open BTP cockpit and navigate to the space applications page. Here identify the deployed app router application and click on it
    2. in the menu on the left side click on the item Environment Variables
    3. copy the whole content in the area called System Provided
    4. paste the content into the file default-env.json then perform these actions:
      • delete the whole json object containing the property VCAP_APPLICATION, just keep the one containing the VCAP_SERVICES property
      • in the object VCAP_SERVICES delete the following properties: destination and html5-apps-repo
      • add a property named destinations at the same level of the property VCAP_SERVICES. Its value must be:
          "destinations":[
      {
          "name":"EventsBooking-app-srv2",
          "url":"https://EventsBooking-app-srv2.dest",
          "proxyHost":"http://127.0.0.1",
          "proxyPort":"8887"
      },{
          "name": "vite-dev-server",
          "url": "http://localhost:5174"
      }
  ]
        In this section you have to add all the destionations the react app will use to get data out of external APIs. In the example above there are declared 2 destinations:
        • EventsBooking-app-srv2: it is the BTP destination targeting the Events Management APIs, will be used by the app to get/store events data. Pay attention to the url parameter, it declares to use the URL defined at BTP destination level, so you don't need to hard code it. Leave the proxy parameters as in the example. These provide to BAS the way to communicate with BTP
        • vite-dev-server: it is the destination targeting the URL of the local running react app. The port reported in the URL is the one defined in the file vite.config.ts. This destination let the local app router to forward the local react app calls to the running vite preview execution

  5. Adjust the xs-app.json file in the dev folder: this activity has the aim to define all the local app router configurations, like for example the welcome page, the routes etc. In this case the configuration is as follow:

     {
     "welcomeFile": "index.html",
     "authenticationMethod": "route",
     "routes": [
         {
             "authenticationType": "xsuaa",
             "csrfProtection": false,
             "source": "^/EventsBooking-app-srv2/(.*)$",
             "destination": "EventsBooking-app-srv2",
             "target": "$1"
         },
         {
             "source": "^/user-api(.*)",
             "target": "$1",
             "service": "sap-approuter-userapi"
         },
         {
             "source": "^(.*)$",
             "target": "/$1",
             "destination": "vite-dev-server",
             "authenticationType": "none"
         }
     ],
     "compression": {
         "enabled": false
     }
 }

    the most important part is the routes array. In this array you have to define all the routes the local app router must use. Rember that the routes are processed from the top (array element 0) to the bottom (array element N). The first that matches is the one executed. In this case the meaning of the routes are:

    1. forward to the destinantion EventsBooking-app-srv2 all the app calls to URL path starting with the prefix /EventsBooking-app-srv2. All these calls are defined in the app as the once to interact with the events managment OData service
    2. forward all the calls with URL path starting with /user-api to the standard sap-approuter-userapi user api service. This service provides data about current logged in user, like user name and authorization scopes assigned see here for more info
    3. this route forwards all the local api calls to the vite preview service running. Each and every time the react app needs to donwload an asset, a css, js, etc files these requests are routed to the preview service. this is the route that makes the magic happens, that allows the developer to test the changes without fully rebuilding the application.

Adjust the xs-app.json for the productive usage

In the previous paragraph you setup the environment for the development phase, but once the app will be built and deployed this doesn't served the productive code. For this reason it is needed to setup the xs-app.json in the app router folder module.

  1. open the xs-app.json file contained in the root folder of the app router module.
  2. setup its content as expected for the prodcutive usage. In this example its content is:
    {
 "authenticationMethod": "route",
 "welcomeFile": "index.html",
 "routes": [
     {
         "authenticationType": "xsuaa",
         "csrfProtection": false,
         "source": "^/EventsBooking-app-srv2/(.*)$",
         "destination": "EventsBooking-app-srv2",
         "target": "$1"
     },
     {
         "source": "^/user-api(.*)",
         "target": "$1",
         "service": "sap-approuter-userapi"
     },
     {
         "source": "^(.*)$",
         "target": "$1",
         "localDir": "dist",
         "cacheControl": "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate"
     }
 ],
 "compression": {
     "enabled": false
 }
}
    the difference with the dev version of the same file is in the third route. This route says to the app router to route all the react app calls, which not have the prefixes defined by the first two ones, to the local folder called dist. This is the folder, set in the vite.config.ts, where the full build process will store the output of the build procedure. In other words, it is the folder containing the productive version of the react app code.

Once the app will be deployed and running, every local app call for downloading assets, files (like css, js, etc) will be forwarded to the content of that folder.

Optimize the mta building procedure

To optimize the mta building procedure proceed as described below:

  1. create a script in the package.json contained in the app router folder with this name and command:

    "build": "cd ../events-app && npm run build"

    this command allows to trigger che building of the react app as soon as the app router module build is triggered (see next paragraphs). The script move the context to the react app folder and run the build script contained there

  2. change the mta.yaml file as following:

in the app router module append the following configuration:

 build-parameters:
     ignore:
     - node_modules
     builder: custom
     commands:
     - npm run build

this configuration avoid to include, in the final mtar file, any node_modules folder and, before build the module, runs the script build created beforehand to trigger the vite build command for the react app

Test the app in dev mode

To test the app in dev mode proceed as following:

  1. open a terminal window
  2. move to the react app folder

  3. run the command

    npm run dev

    this command starts the application in dev mode on port 5174, as per app configuration. No need to rebuild the app the see the changes

  4. open a new terminal window and move in the approuter folder
  5. run the script start-local, this run the app router using the config stored in the dev folder.
  6. run a preview of the app on the port 5000
  7. make any change in the code, refresh the app preview and check whether the change is replicated properly

Test the app in productive mode

To test the app in productive mode, simply bluid the mta.yaml file and deploy the generated mtar.

ATTENTION: if you deploy on the same space where you perfomed the first deployment, you need to get again the environment variables of the app, copy just the property xsuaa and used it to replace the same property in the defaul-env.json file. Remind to stop and restart the local running app router to make the change available

If you don't want to overwrite the value of the property xsuaa, deploy the app in a different space of a different account.

entry.content:
Dear Cocquerel,

Thanks for your comment.

You‚Äôre right that RAP and SAPUI5/Fiori are the strategic technologies for new ABAP developments. However, FPM for Web Dynpro ABAP remains the standard UI framework for a large installed base of business applications, especially in the S/4HANA on-premise and private cloud editions. These applications continue to evolve and comply with current SAP product standards ‚Äî so they are maintained, not legacy!

The FPM GenAI Service brings generative AI interaction into this environment, enabling natural-language operation and automation without requiring a technology migration. For RAP/SAPUI5, there are indeed multiple AI integration paths ‚Äî most prominently through SAP Joule and BTP AI services. Our goal is to connect the FPM GenAI Service with Joule as well, so that customers benefit from a consistent AI experience across both FPM and RAP/Fiori applications.

Best regards,

Simon

entry.title: Conversion of SHIFT-JIS Encoding to UTF-8 Encoding for CSV File
entry.content:
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZCSV_CONVERSION3
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*&
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT ysap_shiftjis_to_utf8_csv.

PARAMETERS:
  p_infile TYPE ibipparms-path, "" Pick the file from system
  p_out    TYPE string. ""Assign a path and file name for output file path

DATA:
  lt_raw_data   TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF x255,
  lv_xstring    TYPE xstring,
  lv_string     TYPE string,
  lv_utf8_xstr  TYPE xstring,
  lt_output_raw TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF x255,
  lv_filelen    TYPE i,
  lv_file       TYPE string.

CLASS cl_abap_conv_in_ce DEFINITION LOAD.
CLASS cl_abap_conv_out_ce DEFINITION LOAD.

AT SELECTION-SCREEN ON VALUE-REQUEST FOR p_infile.
  CALL FUNCTION 'F4_FILENAME'
    EXPORTING
      program_name  = syst-cprog
      dynpro_number = syst-dynnr
    IMPORTING
      file_name     = p_infile.

START-OF-SELECTION.
  " Step 1: Upload Shift-JIS file as binary
  lv_file =  p_infile.
  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_upload
    EXPORTING
      filename   = lv_file
      filetype   = 'BIN'
    IMPORTING
      filelength = lv_filelen
    CHANGING
      data_tab   = lt_raw_data.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE 'File upload failed' TYPE 'E'.
  ENDIF.

  " Step 2: Convert RAW table to XSTRING
  CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_BINARY_TO_XSTRING'
    EXPORTING
      input_length = lv_filelen
    IMPORTING
      buffer       = lv_xstring
    TABLES
      binary_tab   = lt_raw_data
    EXCEPTIONS
      failed       = 1
      OTHERS       = 2.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE 'Conversion of RAW to XSTRING failed' TYPE 'E'.
  ENDIF.

  " Step 3: Decode Shift-JIS XSTRING to ABAP string
  DATA(lo_in) = cl_abap_conv_in_ce=>create( encoding = '8300' ).
  lo_in->convert(
    EXPORTING
      input = lv_xstring
    IMPORTING
      data  = lv_string ).

  " Step 4: Encode ABAP string to UTF-8 XSTRING
  DATA(lo_out) = cl_abap_conv_out_ce=>create( encoding = '4103' ).
  lo_out->convert(
    EXPORTING
      data   = lv_string
    IMPORTING
      buffer = lv_utf8_xstr ).

  " Step 5: Convert UTF-8 XSTRING back to RAW table
  CLEAR lt_output_raw.
  CALL FUNCTION 'SCMS_XSTRING_TO_BINARY'
    EXPORTING
      buffer     = lv_utf8_xstr
    TABLES
      binary_tab = lt_output_raw
    EXCEPTIONS
      failed     = 1
      OTHERS     = 2.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE 'XSTRING to binary conversion failed' TYPE 'E'.
  ENDIF.

  " Step 6: Download as UTF-8 file
  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download
    EXPORTING
      filename                = p_out
      filetype                = 'BIN'
    CHANGING
      data_tab                = lt_output_raw
    EXCEPTIONS
      file_write_error        = 1
      no_batch                = 2
      gui_refuse_filetransfer = 3
      invalid_type            = 4
      unknown_error           = 5
      OTHERS                  = 6.
  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    MESSAGE 'File converted successfully to UTF-8' TYPE 'S'.
  ELSE.
    MESSAGE 'Download failed' TYPE 'E'.
  ENDIF.

entry.title: Re: Foreign currency decimal places setting
entry.content:
Test results for a payment transaction

1). SAP Business One 10.0 (10.00.180) FP 2111 (64-bit)

A USD 10.11 A/R invoice was partially paid with USD 10. Expected result: The 'Payment on Account' field should display -0.11. Actual result: The system rounds the value and leaves the field blank, while another field below shows -0.11.

2). SAP Business One 10.0 (10.00.200) FP 2208 (64-bit)

A USD 16,094.35 A/R invoice was partially paid with USD 16,094. The 'Payment on Account' field correctly displays -0.35.

3). SAP Business One 10.0 version for SAP HANA (10.00.230) SP 2311 (64-bit)

The test result is the same as in case (2).

Additionally, I have confirmed that SAP systems running the same FP2111 version and even older versions (such as 9.2 PL12) produce the same result as in case (1), where the decimal places are not displayed. I suspect this issue might be related to version differences.

entry.title: Re: "Text Through Text Associations" in RAP triggers exce...
entry.content:
I know this is an old question, but I've run into it before, so this is more of a 'note to self' for next time üòÄ

The solution is given here:

Getting Language-Dependent Text in Projection Views | SAP Help Portal

You cannot use the ObjectModel.text.association annotation, but you need to use @ObjectModel.text.element: [<text_element>] and then add the text field from an association and use the 'localized' keyword.

Prerequisites

  • The text provider view has a key element indicating the language of the text.
  • The projected CDS view has an association to the text provider view, but does not use the annotation ObjectModel.text.association.

Procedure

  1. Include the text element from the text provider view into the projection view.
  2. Annotate the element in the projection view, for which you want to provide the text with @ObjectModel.text.element: [<text_element>] and reference the text element.
  3. To get language-dependent texts use the keyword localized on the text element.

entry.title: MRP Should Consider PIR Demand Before Safety Stock During Planning Run
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I‚Äôm currently facing a planning logic requirement related to MRP run behavior with safety stock and Planned Independent Requirements (PIRs).

Below is the current scenario for one material:

  • Available Stock: 900

  • Safety Stock: 1000

  • PIR1: 400

  • PIR2: 500

During the MRP run (MRP type PD), the system first plans to cover the safety stock and then considers the demands.
As a result, the system generates:

Purchase Requisition 1 = 100 (to reach safety stock)
Purchase Requisition 2 = 400 (for PIR1)
Purchase Requisition 3 = 500 (for PIR2)

However, the business requirement is different.
The client wants the system to consider PIRs first using the available stock, and only after demand is covered the system should plan for the safety stock.

So ideally, the system should generate:

Purchase Requisition = 1000 (to restore safety stock, since 900 stock is already there to satisfy the PIR's) 

In other words:

  • The system should consume available stock against PIRs first.

  • Safety stock should be planned only after covering demands.

Is there any standard SAP configuration or setting that allows MRP to consider demand before safety stock?
If not, what would be the recommended approach to achieve this?

Thank you in advance for your guidance!

entry.title: Dynamically Making a Field Read-Only in SAP RAP
entry.content:
Introduction 

 Making a field read-only or non-editable dependent on the value of another field is a frequent requirement. This blog post will explain how to use the RAP model to accomplish this.

The scenario we'll cover is making the VBTYP field read-only based on the value of the AUART  field. 

Setting Up the RAP Application 

Before implementing the dynamic behavior, we need a basic RAP application structure. 

  1. Database Table
@EndUserText.label : 'Data base Table for sales order'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table zdemo_dt_so {
  key vbeln : vbeln_va not null;
  erdat     : erdat;
  ernam     : ernam;
  vbtyp     : vbtypl;
  auart     : auart;
}

  2 . Interface View

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Interface view for sales order'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define root view entity ZDEMO_I_SO as select from zdemo_dt_so
{
    key vbeln as Vbeln,
    erdat as Erdat,
    ernam as Ernam,
    vbtyp as Vbtyp,
    auart as Auart
}

 3 . Projection View

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Projection view for Sales order'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
@Metadata.allowExtensions: true
define root view entity ZDEMO_P_SO as projection on ZDEMO_I_SO
{
    key Vbeln,
    Erdat,
    Ernam,
    Vbtyp,
    Auart
}

  4 . Behavior Definition 

managed implementation in class zbp_demo_i_so unique;
strict ( 2 );
define behavior for ZDEMO_I_SO //alias <alias_name>
persistent table zdemo_dt_so
lock master
authorization master ( instance )
//etag master <field_name>
{
field (features : instance ) Vbtyp ;
validation vbtyp_valid on save { field Auart , Vbtyp ; }
  create;
  update;
  delete;
}
projection;
strict ( 2 );
define behavior for ZDEMO_P_SO //alias <alias_name>
{
  use create;
  use update;
  use delete;
}

  5 .Service Definition and Binding

@EndUserText.label: 'Service def SO'
define service ZDEMO_P_SO {
  expose ZDEMO_P_SO;
}

Once you click on preview you can see the application and create a record

Implementing Dynamic Feature Control 

Our goal is to make the  ,VBTYP field read-only if the AUART field has a specific value, like 'KA'.

For Achieving this scenario first we need to Define a Dynamic feature control for the field 'VBTYP' 

The logic for making the field read-only  presents in the  

get_instance_features method of your behavior implementation class. This method is automatically created  by the RAP framework. Here's the code you'll need to write: 

 METHOD get_instance_features.

  READ ENTITIES OF ZDEMO_I_SO IN LOCAL MODE
   ENTITY zdemo_i_so FIELDS ( Vbeln  Auart )
   WITH CORRESPONDING #( keys )
   RESULT data(lt_result).
        LOOP AT lt_result INTO data(ls_result).
        if ls_result-Auart = 'KA'.
        result = VALUE #(
        (
        %tky = ls_result-%tky
        %features-%field-Vbtyp = if_abap_behv=>fc-f-read_only
        ) ).
        ELSE.
        result = VALUE #(
        (
        %tky = ls_result-%tky
        %features-%field-Vbtyp = if_abap_behv=>fc-f-unrestricted
        ) ).
        ENDIF.
        ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.

After implementing the logic, activate your behavior implementation class. Now, when you refresh your  application, the changes will be applied  

In your application, you can create a few records with different  

AUART values, such as 'KA' and 'OR'. When you try to edit the record where  

AUART is 'KA', you will notice that the VBTYP field is grayed out and you are unable to change its value. However, if you edit a record where 

AUART is 'OR', the VBTYP field will remain editable, allowing you to change its value freely.

This demonstrates how the field's behavior is dynamically controlled. 

Conclusion  :  

The blog post effectively demonstrates how to dynamically make a field read-only within the SAP RAP.  The core method involves using dynamic feature control.

entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Minimum UX you need for SAP Business AI and Clean Core
entry.content:
SAP Fiori is the business user experience (UX) needed for SAP Business AI and Clean Core for SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private.

  1. SAP Fiori is the primary way of bringing SAP Business AI to business users, including SAP‚Äôs digital assistant Joule. SAP Fiori is a prerequisite for embedded AI-assisted features and generative AI use cases.
  2. For Clean Core, SAP Fiori brings the SAP Fiori apps and user experience (UX) features needed for clean processes, extensions, and operations that supports your business users and your technical users through continuous innovation ‚Äì including AI use cases.

Joule diamond icon as it appears in the SAP Fiori launchpad shell bar

In this blog post you will learn why and the minimums you need to get started.

  • Why you need SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private
  • How SAP Fiori works with Joule for business users
  • Minimum UX to get started with Clean Core
  • Minimum UX to get started with SAP Business AI
  • Learnings to support your UX journey

 

Why you need SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private

From the beginning of SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì now over 10 years ago ‚Äì I have been explaining to SAP customers and partners, that SAP Fiori is how SAP delivers the innovations of SAP S/4HANA to business users.

The innovations of SAP S/4HANA include:

  • On-stack innovations ‚Äì innovations available within your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition solution.
  • Side-by-side innovations ‚Äì innovations that extend your solution with cloud services and cloud solutions.

Two (2) top of mind examples of these innovations are:

  • Clean Core processes, extensions, and operations. Many of these are on-stack innovations included in your solution as SAP Fiori apps and launchpad features.
  • SAP Business AI, including Joule ‚Äì your digital assistant ‚Äì and other AI use cases embedded with SAP Cloud ERP Private. These are side-by-side innovations that need flexibility, power, and scale of cloud resources to make them cost-effective.

SAP Fiori user experience is now over 12 years old and has matured to cover a vast range of business and technical processes, across many industries.  More than 3.5K apps are already available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. SAP Best Practices (found in the SAP Signavio Process Navigator) highlight the best of these new processes and apps.

SAP Fiori itself continues to innovate to make it easier for business users to work in new ways; on new device types; and caters for a broad range of working conditions and personal needs. For example:

  • My Home for SAP S/4HANA page introduced with SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01. The AI feature Recommended Apps has been added with SAP S/4HANA 2025,
  • Spaces and pages navigation introduced with SAP S/4HANA 2020 and improved with each SAP S/4HANA release, and
  • Keyboard Shortcuts dialog introduced with SAP S/4HANA 2025 for users who prefer/need keyboard navigation.

My Home for SAP S/4HANA in SAP S/4HANA 2025 showing Recommended Apps tab with recommendations from SAP Business AI

SAP Fiori apps apply consistent floorplans and behaviours that make them quick to learn ‚Äì as per SAP Design System.  For example, Fiori Elements, Smart Business KPIs, and Review Booklets.  These floorplans are already Clean Core compliant, i.e. they automatically update with the latest improvements as you upgrade your SAP S/4HANA release, feature pack stack and/or SAPUI5 version.  This includes relevant AI-assisted features. Even when you have extended the app, clean core extensions such as Custom Fields and Adapt UI are retained.

Hint: If you need to custom-build your own app, using common floorplans greatly reduces development effort and change management effort.  Start your technical team at the UI5 Demo Kit section Developing Apps with SAP Fiori Elements.  Make sure they look at the Flexible Programming Model Explorer in the Resources section of the UI5 Demo Kit. Get them started with Joule for ABAP.

A major strength of the SAP Fiori launchpad is its ability to launch and easily navigate between SAP Fiori apps and classic UIs (including SAP GUI for HTML, ABAP Web Dynpro applications, WebClient UIs) and URLs. This includes your custom-built apps and (aka ‚ÄúZ‚Äù) transactions!

Hint: In workshops I like explain this as the new world of SAP Fiori understands the old world classic UIs and can cater for them.

More than 11.5K classic UIs are pre-configured as ready-to-use launchpad content for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. While Best Practices highlight the best new processes, many quick win apps and features motivate users to move from the classic GUI into a web- and cloud-centric world, such as Search, Share/Bookmark, and Insight Tiles / Insight Cards. 

SAP Business Roles are templates that show how new apps and classic UIs work together to soften the pace of change.  You use the templates as a starting point for your own custom business roles.  By launching all processes from the launchpad, you retain useful classic Uis, combined with new value features, such as personalization, situations, search, embedded analytics, and app-to-app navigation.  For example: app F1873 Manage Sales Orders lets you simplify sales order creation by moving some order types to SAP Fiori and navigate to classic UIs for other order types.

SAP Fiori innovations help business experts and technical teams collaborate to efficiently manage change. It brings no-code/low-code clean core configuration and extension apps, features, and tools to help guide your business users and technical users as you improve your processes over time. For example: SAP Fiori app F1481 Custom Fields to extend end-to-end processes across Fiori apps, classic UIs, analytics, APIs, and much more. 

 

Example of adding Custom Fields to the business context Product General

 

Other important tools and features for managing change include:

  • Adapt UI within apps to control visible/hidden fields/tabs/tables/cards/charts, and provide role-based default settings for filters/tables/charts
  • WYSIWYG editors for launchpad layouts (apps Manage Launchpad Spaces and Manage Launchpad Pages) to communicate recommended/changing tasks for users‚Äô assigned roles
  • Integration with Microsoft Teams for human collaboration
  • Integration with SAP WalkMe for context-sensitive guidance and user behaviour monitoring.

 

Hint: You can provide context-sensitive help via SAP WalkMe as per SAP‚Äôs strategic direction. If you have existing SAP Enable Now content, you can continue to use SAP Companion.

For an extended list of configuration and extension apps refer to SAP Fiori for SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Yes you need SAP Fiori to Configure, Adapt and Extend SAP S/4HANA. With SAP S/4HANA 2025, the new app F8438 Manage News for system news is a very welcome addition (think of it as the next generation of transaction SM02).  

Personal note:

  • At customers we are finding the My Home for SAP S/4HANA page motivates business users to move into the launchpad.  Experienced users like having these attractive personalization options to optimize their day.  For suggestions on how to make the most of this personalization refer to: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori ‚Äì Organizing your My Home page
  • New and time-poor users can be directed to start with the role-based layouts (spaces and pages) via the favorite pages assigned to their role(s). These layouts are easy to configure to reinforce the major processes, activities + on-system tasks of each role.  Layouts can be shared and optionally merged across similar roles.  Layouts respect authorizations by hiding unauthorized tiles, including hiding empty sections and empty pages.  For examples view the SAP Learning video Introducing SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA Cloud [01:33] & further videos in Getting Started with Spaces and Pages. To create your own spaces and pages, refer to SAP Learning video Creating SAP Fiori Launchpad Layouts for Custom Business Roles [11:57]

 

How SAP Fiori works with Joule for business users

Business users authorized for SAP Joule access the Joule web client via the Joule icon on the SAP Fiori launchpad.  The Joule icon appears in the top shell bar of the launchpad ‚Äì making it always available to business user whether they are in a SAP Fiori app or a classic UI.

 

Joule diamond icon as it appears in the SAP Fiori launchpad shell bar

 

SAP Fiori provides much more than a button to open a dialog window.

Both Joule navigational use cases and transactional use cases rely on the intent-based navigation of SAP Fiori when suggesting users take next steps in a relevant app.

You can find the apps of Joule navigational use cases in SAP Help - SAP Joule - Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition ‚Äì Finding Apps with Navigational Capability  The apps used in navigational use cases are SAP Fiori apps. The user must be authorized to launch the target app from the launchpad.

Example Joule navigational use case for show sales orders. More details are accessed through the Open button against each Sales Order/Item, navigating to the Manage Sales Order app

Joule transactional use cases enable users to quickly perform tasks in Joule instead of using an app, then optionally navigate to an app to check the result. The user must be authorized to perform the task, and to launch the target app from the launchpad.

Example prompts for transactional use cases with Sales Orders in SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private

Hint: Target apps are launched by using SAP Fiori intent-based navigation. The intent is a Semantic Object + Action pair. You can find the matching apps and UIs using the tools of the Fiori Foundation Administrator role. For example: Launchpad App Manager, Launchpad Content Manager Client-Specific, or the read-only tool Launchpad Content Aggregator.

Most embedded AI use cases depend on using SAP Joule, accessing apps via SAP Fiori launchpad, and/or using key user tools in SAP Fiori. You can find the embedded AI use cases listed SAP Note 3558794 - AI Functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

For example, AI-assisted Maintenance Order Recommendations you need:

  • SAP Fiori app F4470 Intelligent Scenario Management to train/activate the underlying AI model
  • SAP Fiori app F4604 Manage Maintenance Notifications and Orders for business users to use the AI

What about your own Joule use case created with SAP Joule Studio? Can you navigate to custom-built SAP Fiori apps or classic UIs for your own use cases? Yes, you can!

By using the intent-based navigation of the SAP Fiori launchpad to navigate to the relevant app or classic UI.  For some ideas on how agentic use cases may work with upcoming Joule Agents refer to High-Impact Use Cases of SAP Joule AI Agents

Minimum UX to get started with Clean Core

To get started with Clean Core, as a minimum you need to:

  • Activate your on-stack (aka local) SAP Fiori launchpad.
  • The activation process by default generates an every-user Fiori Foundation User role for basic launchpad access + a Fiori Foundation Administration role to manage your launchpad content and layouts.

Hint: Check with your ECS team - or take a look in transaction STC02 - as for many customers launchpad activation will already have been done for you. If not, you can activate your launchpad yourself using rapid activation, or you can request your ECS team to do this for you.  

Depending on your starting point, you then need to activate one or more roles and assign these roles to your users, in addition to the every-user Fiori Foundation User role for basic launchpad access.

 

Summary of the 5 Clean Core Principles: Processes, Extensibility, Data, Integration, Operations

For Clean Core Processes, SAP Fiori delivers the SAP Fiori apps and features you will find in Best Practices, along with many other apps that support simpler, more consistent ways of working.

To get started with on-stack Clean Core processes, as a minimum you need to:

  • Activate the SAP Business Role(s) listed in your selected best practices

The rapid activation process creates a copy of the role in the customer namespace ready to refine. Once you have explored the role and the process, you then use the Fiori Foundation Administration role to refine it for your needs.  

For Clean Core Extensibility, SAP Fiori brings to business users (key users) and developers the Level A upgrade-safe, no-code/low-code - aka ‚Äúkey user‚Äù - tools you need to extend your business solution rapidly and cleanly. 

Hint: For the full Clean Core extension model refer to: Clean core extensibility for SAP S/4HANA Cloud. For a quick end-to-end on Clean Core references for your team refer to: ‚ÄúBusiness Excellence with SAP‚Äôs New Clean Core Extensibility Levels: Why, What and How‚Äù

To get started with on-stack Clean Core extensions, as a minimum you need to:

  • Activate the business role Extensibility Specialist (id SAP_BR_EXTENSIBILITY_SPEC).

Extensibility Specialist page showing the apps assigned

This role is assigned the major key user tools + the Adapt UI feature. You should assign this role to your key users ‚Äì who may include business experts and your technical team.

To use Adapt UI, your key users will also need access to the app (or app variant) you want them to adapt. 

For further guidance and examples refer to: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì What is Key User Extensibility and Who are your Key Users

Depending on which apps and features you want to start with, you may also need the role Analytics Specialist for key user tools to manage your embedded analytics.  

Hint: The Analytics Specialist role includes the SAP Fiori app F2170 View Browser which provides a quick way to find released CDS Views for clean core extensions and integrations.

Example of the app View Browser in SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS00 showing the app view Released Views for Key Users

For Clean Core Operations, SAP Fiori delivers administration and support tools to help you manage your solution, including your clean core processes and on-stack clean core extensions. For example, SAP Fiori app F1589 Register Extensions for Transport 

Example of app Register Extensions for Transport where key user extensions are assigned to transport requests

To get started with on-stack Clean Core operations, as a minimum you need to:

  • Activate the SAP Business Role Administrator (SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR) 

Hint: If your ECS team have activated your SAP Fiori launchpad for you, they will also have activated the Administrator role.

You should also apply the latest innovations for the App Support launchpad feature and make it available to all your launchpad users.  App Support provides an easy capture of logs, authorization errors, and technical details (app id, UI type, SAPUI5 version, device type, browser OS, etc) directly from the user‚Äôs session. You can even authorize your technical team to view/capture errors on behalf of the user.

Refer to:

  • SAP Help ‚Äì SAP Fiori launchpad - Administration Guide ‚Äì Setting up App Support
  • SAP blog SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì New improvements in App Support

 

Minimum UX to get started with SAP Business AI

For SAP Business AI, SAP Fiori launchpad provides business users access to SAP Joule, access to navigational and transactional capabilities, plus apps and tools that support embedded AI use cases.

To get started with SAP Joule, a side-by-side innovation, as a minimum you need to:

1. Meet commercial prerequisites

  • Have signed the relevant AI Terms and AI Usage agreements
  • Have subscribed to the cloud services needed for your AI use case

2. In your SAP S/4HANA solution:

  • Activate your on-stack (aka ‚Äúlocal‚Äù) SAP Fiori launchpad
  • Activate the (SAP or custom) business roles you want to use with AI
  • Assign users to the business roles you want to use with AI

3. In SAP Build Work Zone solution:

  • Activate your unified (aka ‚Äúcentral‚Äù) SAP Fiori launchpad on SAP Build Work Zone
  • Federate the content of your business roles from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Build Work Zone
  • Federate your user-to-role assignments from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Build Work Zone
  • Activate the Joule icon in your central launchpad and local launchpad

For the quickest way to make this happen refer to Joule provisioning with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition using Cloud Integration Automation service.  This CIAS automates 80% of the setup and guides you through the rest.

If you are new to SAP Build Work Zone and need some background on the architecture and other technical options, refer to Joule - Unified Setup: Bridging Simplicity and Performance.

For understanding your SAP Build Work Zone configuration you can refer to SAP Learning Journey: Setting Up SAP Build Work Zone standard edition and SAP Mobile Start with SAP S/4HANA

Which roles do you need to activate

For Joule navigational and transactional use cases, you will need to activate the roles (SAP Business Roles or equivalent custom roles) you need for your selected line of business (LoB) use cases.

You can find the list of current Joule use cases and their requirements in SAP Note 3523238 - Navigational and Transactional capabilities with Joule in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

For embedded AI use cases:

  • You will need to activate the roles (SAP Business Roles or equivalent custom roles) you need as explained in the use case documentation
  • You may also need to activate the role Analytics Specialist on your local launchpad. This role contains the apps to configure, train, and activate underlying machine learning and generative AI models. For example, app F4469 Intelligent Scenarios.

Hint: If your ECS team have activated your SAP Fiori launchpad for you, they will also have activated the Analytics Specialist role.

Hint: The documentation for each use case in the SAP Business AI discovery center explains which apps are required. 

 

Why 2 launchpads ‚Äì the local and the central launchpad

The launchpad of SAP Build Work Zone (BWZ) acts a central access point to multiple cloud solutions.  To preserve the maximum functionality of the original solutions, the central launchpad launches apps in the local cloud solution.

SAP Build Work Zone federates the content ‚Äì i.e. the roles, the layouts, the user assignments ‚Äì from the local cloud solutions. It can also provide a central access point for federated features such as inbox tasks (SAP Task Center), notifications, searches, and more. These features also navigate to the relevant target app in the local launchpad.

The same is true for SAP Mobile Start which you should think of as the central launchpad on your mobile device, providing an online mobile entry point to apps and features.  Launching an app on a mobile device will reformat the appearance of the app and replace keyboard behaviours with mobile touch equivalents.

The implication is you must have a local launchpad as:

  • A source of launchpad content and layouts
  • A source of user-to-role assignments
  • As a target for launching apps and features.

Which launchpad should your user log into?  Either! It‚Äôs your choice. 

Once the prerequisites are met, you can choose to run Joule from the central launchpad or from the local launchpad.  This gives you some flexibility in both change management for users and consumption of services. 

In practice, this will depend on your preferences, subscriptions, and commercial agreements:

  • If all your users are covered under your SAP Build Work Zone subscription, and you are happy for your users to work over the internet, you direct them to the SAP Build Work Zone launchpad.
  • If your subscription only covers a portion of your user base, or you need to restrict internet access, you can split your user base to the 2 launchpads if you wish.

As a rule of thumb, you must activate the central launchpad for AI, mobile, and internet desktop use cases. The more cloud solutions and cloud services you use, the more value you will get from the central launchpad.

Some customers take a tactical approach while they grow scope and skills, by directing users who are primarily desktop/intranet to the local launchpad, while users who are primarily mobile use the central launchpad. 

 

Learnings to get you started

 

If your team is new to SAP Fiori, start with the SAP Learning Journey Learning the Basics of SAP Fiori. To keep your technical team aligned with your User Experience strategy:

  • For launchpad content administrators ‚Äì SAP Learning video Bringing Apps Onto SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition [05:25] and SAP Learning Journey Designing SAP Build Work Zone
  • For security administrators - SAP Learning Journey:  Exploring the fundamentals of SAP System Security which includes SAP Fiori security and SAP Build Work Zone security.
  • For analytics specialists - SAP Learning Journey: Discovering SAP S/4HANA embedded analytics
  • For administrators: SAP Learning Journeys Implementing and Administering SAP Build Work Zone and Administrating SAP Business Technology Platform and to SAP Learning Journey: Setting Up SAP Build Work Zone standard edition and SAP Mobile Start with SAP S/4HANA

These are complemented by a growing number of short (max 12 minute) learning videos on SAP Learning for optional and self-managed tasks. For example:

  • Introducing SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA Cloud
  • Activating SAP Fiori Launchpad Using SAP Fiori Foundation Task List 
  • Bringing Apps Onto SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA Cloud and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition
  • Configuring the SAP Fiori Launchpad for SAP S/4HANA
  • Creating SAP Fiori Launchpad Layouts for Custom Business Roles
  • Adapting the UI of List Report Apps with SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA
  • Patching SAP Fiori (SAPUI5)

You will find supplementary blog posts for deeper dives on our SAP Community  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page including: 

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Adding a GUI transaction to the launchpad in SAP S/4HANA 2023 or higher
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori ‚Äì Organizing your My Home page
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori ‚Äì Navigate with confidence

SAP Activate resources:

  • For how to create your UX Strategy, you will find content and accelerators for UX Adoption. For all UX Adoption content and accelerators select the tag "User Experience" Refer to Run the Establish the Business Value of User Experience Workshop and Define the UX / UI Strategy.
     

Hint: We are currently updating the UX Adoption accelerators for AI, Clean Core, and SAP S/4HANA 2025 based on latest information and running these workshops with many customers worldwide. These updates are planned to be released before the end of 2025. 

  • For getting started with Clean Core you will find the tag Clean Core Success Plan in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private roadmaps

SAP Activate roadmaps for SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP Private

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

You‚Äôll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG and Customer Care team

entry.title: How Can Organizations Architect a Scalable Data Engineering Pipeline to Support Real-Time AI-Driven
entry.content:
How Can Organizations Architect a Scalable Data Engineering Pipeline to Support Real-Time AI-Driven Decision Making Across Multiple Domains?

Hello everyone,

I‚Äôm working on designing a data engineering pipeline that can support real-time AI analytics across multiple business domains, including marketing, operations, and supply chain. I want to ensure that our architecture is scalable, resilient, and compliant with data privacy regulations.

Specifically, I‚Äôm looking for insights on:

Data Ingestion & Streaming: What are the best practices for ingesting large-scale structured and unstructured data in near real-time? Which tools or frameworks are most effective for multi-source streaming pipelines?

Data Storage & Modeling: How can we efficiently store both batch and streaming data while maintaining a single source of truth for AI models? Are there recommended data lake or warehouse strategies?

Feature Engineering for AI: How can feature pipelines be automated and monitored to ensure high-quality inputs for machine learning models without introducing bias?

Real-Time Model Deployment: What architecture patterns (e.g., event-driven, micro-batching, or hybrid) best support real-time AI inference while minimizing latency?

Governance & Compliance: How do organizations ensure data privacy, lineage, and regulatory compliance while enabling agile AI experimentation?

Has anyone implemented a production-ready solution that addresses these challenges? I‚Äôd love to hear about architectural choices, tool recommendations, pitfalls, and lessons learned from real-world implementations.

entry.title: Trigger a workflow when a job is scheduled
entry.content:
Hello everyone!

Requirement

Basically I need an ABAP method to be called each time a SAP job is created/scheduled. 
After googling, I found the BOR object "BPJOB" with the event "SCHEDULED". So I thought I could fulfill the requirement by triggering a workflow from this event.

What I have done

I have created the z-class and the workflow. I have successfully tested both.
For the trigger, I identified the BOR-object "BPJOB" with its event "SCHEDULED".
I also checked and rechecked the linkage (transaction SWE2) from the BOR object/event to the workflow. This works, as I can successfully test everything in the transaction SWUE.

The problem

When I now try to schedule a job manually by executing a dummy report in the background, nothing happens. As far as I can tell, the event is not triggered.

This now leads me to believe that I have not understood the functionality of these BOR objects and events correctly. I assumed that the event will be triggered in SAP standard each time a job is scheduled. Is that not the case?

How are these events triggered? Can they only be triggered in z-coding?

What other options do I have to possibly achieve my requirement?

Thank you for your support!
Greeting, Nick

entry.title: Re: Unable to Post Direct Activity Allocation to Event-Ba...
entry.content:
Hi Vero,
Yes, let me explain you more and what you can do achive you want to. Please find below the detail explanation.

SSCUI: Activate Account Assignment to Activity Types
As of version 2508, the SSCUI ‚ÄúActivate Account Assignment to Activity Types‚Äù appears to be deprecated or no longer directly accessible via the standard SSCUI catalog. This aligns with SAP‚Äôs broader shift toward centralized configuration via CBC (Central Business Configuration) and role-based access to configuration apps. Now you must check if the configuration is now embedded in CBC activity groups or business configuration sets.
Alternatively, verify whether the Controlling Area settings for fiscal year 2025 include the activation of account assignment to activity types. This may now be managed via Manage Your Solution ‚Üí Configure Your Solution ‚Üí Controlling ‚Üí Cost Center Accounting.

G/L Account 55110000 ‚Äì Blocked for Posting
You're absolutely right that this account may not be explicitly referenced in account determination SSCUIs. However, SAP may still derive it from secondary cost element settings or activity type master data. My suggestions are to check the activity type master data (via ‚ÄúManage Activity Types‚Äù) and see if account 55110000 is assigned as the default cost element. Review the cost element category for 55110000 ‚Äî if it‚Äôs set as a secondary cost element for internal activity allocation, it may be automatically picked up. Also check CO version settings and plan/actual integration ‚Äî sometimes blocked accounts are referenced indirectly through planning profiles.

WBS Element Configuration
It sounds like your WBS element setup is solid. Since it‚Äôs released and assigned to an investment profile that allows internal activity allocation, the issue likely lies elsewhere ‚Äî possibly in how the system interprets event-based logic during posting.

Use of F3697A in Event-Based Projects
You're absolutely correct ‚Äî SAP Help Portal explicitly lists Manage Direct Activity Allocation (F3697A) as a supported app for event-based investment projects. However, SAP Community reports suggest that certain combinations of cost elements, activity types, or fiscal year settings may still cause issues.


Today the app is supported, but only under specific conditions ‚Äî including proper activation of account assignment, unblocked cost elements, and compatible fiscal year settings. If the fiscal year 2025 is not activated for account assignment in CO area A000, the system will reject the posting even if everything else is correct.


Here is what i recommended steps for you,
Check Fiscal Year Settings:
Use CBC or configuration apps to confirm that account assignment to activity types is active for 2025 in CO area A000.

Review Activity Type Master Data:
Confirm that the correct secondary cost element is assigned and that it‚Äôs not blocked.

Explore CBC or Raise an SAP Incident:
If you cannot locate the SSCUI or CBC activity, consider raising a support ticket to confirm whether the configuration has been migrated or renamed.

Hope the above explanation is okay with you.
